												Combine and Rebels.I played Half-Life 2 for the first time in 2004 when Steam started to exist (tho on my LICENSED DISK I had no steam oddly enough) and Half-Life 2 gave a lot of bugs with AI_DISABLED error. I was (around) 10 years old back then.I was always imagining built bases when I was in toilet taking a dump. A corner of the bathroom was always a base of Rebels and I always imagined like a scrap yard (with crates and stuff) stacked and having those rebels collect it to build villages. This was roughly 7-8 years ago (I am 20 now).Later, around 3 years after I was drawing this kind of thing on a sheet. I imagined mini-citadels constructed by The Combine and Rebels on the other corner of this sheet. There were empty bases you could capture and use for improving one's side.2009 - This was the first time I met "Half-Life 2 Wars", it was in early alpha stage and was practically completely undeveloped. It was running on HL2:DM engine and you could already select units with your mouse and move them around (though, I must admit, they were really buggy, since the path finding for bots was terrible back then). I played it a bit, though I did not understand it was Early Alpha and simply forgot about it.2 more years after, when I learned mapping with Hammer Editor I made a few large maps with some already built-in bases. Shame they weren't that detailed and they server no purpose. But at least I got what I wanted to see.So I imagined all this and hoped that one day this would turn into a Strategy game. And it did. And funnily enough, would it be a coincidence - it all came out exactly in the way I imagined when I was a kid! This is like a dream!!!I don't know how else I can express my emotions, when I tried out Lambda Wars (previously known as Half-Life 2 Wars), I was not simply impressed and excited. I was happy. Half-Life universe is the universe I always loved more than any other (even S.T.A.L.K.E.R or Metro 2033; any other post-apocalyptic environment).I always wanted to be able to manipulate Combine forces. I got to do that during 13.1 hours of my CURRENT (as I write this) gameplay.I am willing to help this mod improve any way possible. I am ready for anything, I am ready to put all my effort of mapping into it, texturing and sound editing, because this genre was always my favourite. But now with HL2 universe?F#ck yeah!P.S: To all who find this game 'boring' - don't bother then. Why? If you never played Comand & Conquer or Age of Empires, or you simply didn't find it "your thing" you will never understand how it feels to play a RTS version of Half-Life 2. Oh boy, especially if you haven't played Half-Life 2. Or don't like it.P.S 2: I heard Zombie faction (or Antlion faction) will appear later on. Man how awesome can it be?

												Doing perfectly fine for a beta. I've always been a big fan of the Half-Life universe, and seeing it reach out to real-time strategy rather than step back into more of the same FPS element makes me, and countless other fans very happy. Good soundtrack, decent-looking UI, and acceptable sound quality. I'd also like to say I really like the way the developers engaged and adapted Half-Life's assets from FPS to RTS. For example being given the ability to build Headcrab Canister Launchers when playing as the Combine and then bomb the ♥♥♥♥ out of the Rebels, or giving the Rebels the ability to enable a blitz buff when you send your rebellious, defiant units to rush into Combine territory. As far as my complaints and requests, I'd say the AI is at times really silly, but I guess AI will always be annoying especially in this sort of game. It would be good to see more maps, and greater map detail as well, albeit I'm certain the developers are already working on it at the moment. Another thing that would be fantastic would be another faction, one for the Antlions. 												Great mod and better yet, better than a lot of RTS games out there. The mod is heavily based on Company of Heroes mechanics but if you're like me, then it's a welcome variation. It almost feels like Valve created a Half Life RTS game. The iconic source-engine physics are all there with bodies flying across the map and dragging on the pavement after they're hit by an explosion to manhacks bouncing off of enemy soldier's bodies. This game won't alienate you if you just want Half Life but with an RTS twist.The game lets you play with friends or with bots, like every RTS game SHOULD (I'm looking at you Men of War). You can play the classic game-modes such as Annihilation and Headquarters, but there's some fun variation with Overrun (survival) and Sandbox (spawn, build, whatever). This has very good variation for a mod. Considering that I've grown tired of RTS games since the release of anticipated titles such as Rome 2 Total War (huge let-down for me), I surprisingly had a lot of fun with this. Just playing Co-op zombie survival with friends makes this worth trying out.A BIG plus for me is the fact that this MOD (emphasis on MOD) has base building. Some of my favorite franchises with bigger budgets don't have this and have fallen from grace (DAWN OF WAR DAWN OF WAR DAWN OF WAR). If you have played Company of Heroes, then the resource collection in the game works exactly the same (capture flags, fortify them, etc). Base-building is also very similar except you can build ANYWHERE on the map. There is also a simple research system that is required to unlock certain units/weapons.Negatives: (mainly minor flaws)-The amount of content in terms of units and buildings is a little low (for controlled factions such as Rebels and Combine). There are quite a few more units but you can't control them (Antlions and Zombies). -The A.I. is also on the slow side. It pretty much travels in clusters with anywhere from 3 to 40 units travelling in a condensed pack (really hit my FPS if playing with more players). -This one may just be down to preference, but it felt odd that there were no vehicles considering that vehicles were a huge part of Half Life 2. Unless you count the Combine Strider (yes they're in the game) as a vehicle.-Some pathing issues (lost a game because half my units got stuck behind a turret I deployed lol).-Lack of permanent commands. I can click on "Hold position" to keep them from comitting suicide, but they CAN'T perform ANY actions afterwards or the "Hold Position" command gets thrown out the window and they proceed to then commit suicide as usual. There's really only "Hold Position", "Attack Target", and "Patrol".Other than that, the game is awesome. It has the Half Life 2 sounds. Common enemies such as the antlions and headcrabs return. Source physics. Very good adaption of Half Life 2 into an RTS game. Recommended you try it out!

												I'm a few hours in, and it seems solid.Now, I don't know how it holds up with HL2 lore, (I'm not a geek, bite me) but I can definetly say that the engine is stable and functional, which is an accomplishment in its own right. That said it has some minor issues, but given the beta state, they may be overlooked... But may need fixing.But before we get to that, let me talk about the things I liked. First of all, the engine is still a bit... Gmodish which means stuff's gonna fly all over the place. Building debrees, unit corpses, random junk, all sorts of stuff. Even units - at one point in sp_abandoned a fast zombie lunged at one of my units and went skydiving after it bounced off a pile of garbage. Things like this keep the game _slightly_ unpredictible which makes it a little more fun, as there's a slight chance that 2 setups will have different results. I see it as a merit, even though some may see it as a flaw.Another thing I like is the fact that in order to do damage, you actually have to hit the enemy units. For example if a Shotgun Rebel will try to turn around and pump a combine full of lead, he may miss. Why? Because he fired before he finished turning around. It may not seem all that afir but honestly, I kinda see where the creators are coming from. This also means that shotguns won't just do fixed damage at a short range, but instead can be used as a strong short distance weapon and a weak mid-range weapon. Kudos.I also like that you don't have to build your buildings to a grid. Even though I think it should be an option, it'd be best if it was an OPTION. Aka, you can both snap to grid and freeplace them. Rotating buildings would also be a welcome feature, in case I missed it, and it would allow for some creative base construction. At the very least allow the structures to be rotated 90 degrees.What I don't like is the text-based, minimalistic interface, but again, it's a Beta. Their priority should be making the game functional and balanced before they hone the visuals.Also while I understand the whole "shortcut corresponds to icon placement" concept, I found it very, very, very, very counter-intuitive, especially after Blizzard's rise to power and their use of contextual naming of the shortcuts - A for Attack, also for Offensive Movement, B for building, S for stopping (oh also, you don't have a "STOP" command. There's only a"HOLD GROUND") I went out of my way to re-bind those just so I can more or less normally play with what I'm used to since childhood. That said, I can see the merits of such control scheme, but it's simply not what I like.Another gripe I have with this game is a pretty serious issue, especially on maps like sp_abandoned. INTERACTIVE OBJECTS (such as weapon crates, fruit and other) WILL GO INVISIBLE IF THE CAMERA'S FAR OUT ENOUGH. While I admit that it's fair to include this feature, someone should make sure that THE FADING DOESN'T OCCUR WHEN THE CAMERA IS ZOOMED OUT TO THE MAX! Why? Well duh, otherwise how are you gonna see the crates? And in strategy games, the bigger your field of view is, the better. Imagine if you had to play Starcraft or Red Alert using a camera that only allows you to see one tile at a time! Granted, zooming in one step is enough to make the objects visible, but that means you either have to spend the entire game on a reduced screen, or randomly zoom in back and forth like a toddler with a camcorder just to check the objects for being present.Another thing, again having something to do with sp_abandoned. As you may accidentally find out, the various gas cans and carnisters EXPLODE!!!!!111!!1!!1i1!1oneoneone! That's fine, I'll just order my troops to shoot them so they're not a threa- *soldier wals onto the can, dies* Ooookaaay Maybe I'll blow them up with a grenade. *throws a grenade to get rid of 2 carnisters, aiming somewhere between them* Nothing? Maybe I didn't throw it close enough. *throws another one, aiming bullseye to blow it up, nothing* Well, those grenades are wasted. Greeeeeeeeaaat... I think the devs should make it possible to shoot those damn things, or at least make them grenadable. After all, they cost 10rq, might as well make them worth using, right?As I said, it's beta and needs polish. I hope that they'll at least include different cursors depending on what you're ordering your units to do. Right-clicking an enemy makes the same animation as telling them to walk on him, and they don't have an alternate response that would vocally differenciate their attacks from their movements.And I believe they included a custom music option... Which I haven't tried yet, but if it works, SHUT UP AND TAKE MY MONEY!While not the perfect title, it's pretty good. If you can get past the 3 major problems, which are... bearable, you get a neat little mod that, if given some polishing and a campain editor, is probably gonna be a pretty solid title. In fact, I'm looking forward to seeing this come out as a full title. Perhaps the devs could use what they learned to make their own RTS in the future? I'd definetly buy that, if it's at least as solid as Lambda Wars.

												Reviewed 12/23/14A very coherent and fun RTS that makes full use of the Half Life universe.Pros:+ IT'S FREE!!!!!+ Original soundtrack. Sounds like the original Half Life 2 soundtrack with hard-hitting guitar riffs mingled with technical shizwaz.+ Both factions play very differently and are viable. Rebels have strength in numbers and are a more direct smashmouth play style. Combine are best played by distributing the very powerful units on their own.+ Multiple maps that are a little direct but are well designed for the most part.+ Online and offline modes, plus a few designed "campaign" missions.Cons:- Semi-frequent bugs. It's a beta and a community made mod for Christ sake, though.- Units and UI can be a little finnicky and difficult to navigate sometimes. - AI is fairly easy to contend with, even on its hardest difficulty setting.- Some structures, particularly the defensive buildings, don't see much use, as a game can be won easily with fast unit mobilization.- (Personal preference) games don't usually extend for a particularly long time in my experience. No more than 10-20 minutes. From an RTS, I'd love to see an Age of Empires length game mode.- Only a couple songs in the soundtrack so far.Great tribute to Half Life in a completely new format. Enjoying kicking my friends' asses. I'd love to see a more feasible AI/campaign battle component in much larger, grander battles. Absolutely reccomend in its current state.

Posted: December 14, 2014
												I highly recommend this game, especially if you have friends to play it with. It really feels like you are looking over a giant (beautiful) overview of a Half-Life 2 map, while commanding troops at your disposal. Even if you aren't a big fan of RTS games, like me, this game is amazing. Every enemy and ally in Half-Life 2 is in this game, and all of them have a completely different strategy and also have a great purpose, no matter what stage you are in the game. You play as the Rebels and the Combine, and both are COMPLETELY different. The combine have very powerful, but very expensive troops like striders, hunters, snipers, ect., and the rebels have less expensive but less powerful troops like refugees, rebels, medics, ect.The rebels do have more powerful troops like flamers and people with rpgs, but you don't need to use those very much.The rebels and combine are different down to how they heal, how they get energy, what troops you use to build, and even down to what fortifications you make. Overall this is an amazing game, but as it is in beta, there are some major issues. Sometimes when you join a random public server, it bugs out and you aren't able to get in, but that is usually if you have over 200 ping. The AI pathfinding also needs a good amount of work too. They will sometimes get stuck in barricades, but usually only if they are very close together. The things it needs is just an easier way to delete buildings (instead of ordering troops to shoot at it by pressing z and clicking on the building), and just a little more balancing, but thats pretty much it for issues. Overall, this game is amazing, and I cant wait to see it in the full version.

												This game is probably one of the best RTS games that I have played in a while. It reminds me heavily of Halo Wars, which I was and still am a huge fan of, but in Lambda Wars, it's similar to Halo Wars but has more freedom. You can place your buildings almost anywhere you want, which is a step up from designated areas in other RTS games. The soundtrack is good but it only has a few songs. (Which get monotonous quite quickly.) There is also not much that you can do in the lobby before a game. i.e. kick players. There is also a bug that after a game, you pretty much have to recreate the lobby and invite everyone again. But the game is more good than bad, and I was surprised that I spent 2 hours on this in my first sitting. This game truely has potential, and I'm hoping that the devs can make this the game that it deserves to be.Pros:You can build anywhere2 unique factionsaddictive gameplayNice community (from what I've seen so far)GREAT maps (Best one is synth)Easy to Learn! Hard to Master!Cons:Limited game lobby commandsCombine snipers one-hit almost any unit (pls nerf. The first person who brings out snipers is the♥♥♥♥♥♥of the game)Only a few songs in the soundtrack (Why not add some original Half-Life OSTs?)Keep in mind that this game is only in beta, and it's already better than the fully developed CoD: AW that just came out also... Yeah. But what am I saying? Get the game and come join in on the fun!Overall, I give this game an 8/10 kernals. (This score will probably rise whenever updates are released.)

												As of now, this is one of the best MODS that I have ever seen. To think this started as just a alien swarm mod turned standalone, this is truly as masterpeice. I would go over into every part/aspect of the game, but this is not a full review.Everything as of now is solid, but there are two complaints that hold this mod back from anything higher than a 8/10. The next complaint is the Unit system itself, if you are going to have Cover It really shouldnt be single unit based (like in C&C), it should be squad based (like in CoH).(various walls and such provide cover in this game, reducing damage, though sometimes seems to make no sense as cover is not directional, rather static and even if someone is standing behind a wall but his back is totally exposed it still has the damage reduction even though said unit is totally exposed) These minor complaints are probably going to get fixed shortly, as the dev team is very open to the community.I would love to see valve indorse or at least support the devs of this mod, as this is just stunning. Overall, gameplay is fun, but gets dry and repetitive a few hours in. I really want to give this game a higher score, but considering the combination of nasty GUI and balance issues, as well as a semi-broken singleplayer, I can't give it anything higher than a 6/10.

												Tbh, I LOVE THIS GAME.  However, I cannot recommend a game that wastes so many opportunities to be more when the devs chain it to a lore chair that restricts so many amazing ideas from becoming reality.  From the limited amount of factions and maps (ONLY TWO FACTIONS?!) to only 1-3 gamemodes, with one being a total cluster♥♥♥♥ to play with when online (Overrun), Lambda Wars does what fans dream of in terms of a Half-Life 2 fan-game, but fails greatly to be something more than a lore-fan's wet dream.Half-Life is more than Half-Life 2 and, unfortunately, that mindset restricts the true potential of this game from blossoming.  It has the making of a great RTS game, with a mix of classic C&C base-building and combat with modern aspects of resource collection and territory control.  It's a great mix that succeeds to go beyond the classic RTS experience, but it's own concept holds the game back.  The lack of imagination here is TERRIFYING and really allows one faction to ♥♥♥♥ the other one over.  It's not really fair when the Combine has access to infantry-chewing units when the Rebels can ONLY BUILD INFANTRY (Excluding Dog).  The patch fixes help, but that can't help a Rebel player from getting♥♥♥♥♥♥♥by an army of massive walkers camping your base.  This game suffers from its own ultimate goal to stick to Half-Life 2 lore.  This needs to STOP.  LIKE, NOW.  I prefer the Rebels over the Combine because of their infantry, but I can't play this game as much knowing that the Combine EATS INFANTRY FOR BREAKFAST.  It makes matches extremely unenjoyable when you become the victim of walker♥♥♥♥♥♥.. NOT ENJOYABLE.If you're looking for two detailed factions, DON'T LOOK HERE.  There is no such thing as balance in Lambda Wars, especially when it comes to the Rebels and Combine factions... ALSO ESPECIALLY IF THEY'RE THE ONLY TWO DAMN PLAYABLE FACTIONS.  The Combine are slow to start, but can become GODS when they get the ability to deploy walkers and heavy infantry.  The Rebels... not so much.  Their special ops infantry are USELESS in combat when walkers get deployed.  Even the RPG Troopers get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥because of the fact that they are as weak as hell and this forces you to pick from the other weak infantry units, like the Rebel Veteran, who loads ever so slow after firing a one-hit-kill shot (two shots for heavy infantry).  The Rebel Flamer does nothing because the Combine keeps the Rebel FACTION far away, making shotguners and flamers completely useless.  The only real reason to use the flamer is if you somehow gain access to the enemy base after BASE-RUSHING him with cheap Rebel infantry units.  This game isn't all bad.  It's fun to play when you're not getting owned as the Rebels.  In fact, the fun factor is way up there if you play as the Combine because it's easier to win matches as the Combine.  Also, I don't know if you realize this, but damn is this game limited in options in terms of defense buildings and structures.  The Rebels have useless defense structures that are just a pain to use while the Combine just laugh at you while you attack their defenses.  I can't remember a single match while playing as the Rebels in a 1v1 match where I actually breached the Combine defenses... AT ALL.  The only way I could do if, if I could, would've been to ZERG RUSH THE BASE.  NO STRATEGY REQUIRED.  JUST THROW YOUR UNITS INTO THE ENEMY DEFENSES LIKE AN IDIOT.  Look... this game has so much potential, but it's wasted and restricted by this headache of a focus that is "FOR THE LORE'S SAKE".  Games kill themselves if they drown it in lore and only lore-specific stuff.  It needs more content, more imagination, more modes, more factions, more upgrades, more weapons, more units, more campaigns, more EVERYTHING.  It's still being developed, but it's still sad to see a game like this waste some potential that could've made this an easy download.  The devs ARE AMAZING PEOPLE and deserve positive feedback with what they've accomplished, but they need to realize that there's more potential in this game.  They're talent is spectacular and if only they realized the potential of this game, it could've been something more than Half-Life 2 as an RTS.  Look at Halo Wars, a spin-off in the Halo series.  It fit well into the lore while being INVENTIVE and CREATIVE with its units and factions.  Only two factions were featured, but there were uniqure units and upgrades for both of them, which had three commanders each faction with almost more than six or more unique units, upgrades and abilities.  If Lambda Wars wants to be an amazing game, it has to break the chains and expand itself to include a wealth of content that expands BOTH HL games.I wanted to recommend this game, but, unfortunately I can't when this game is drowning itself in its own lore, which is restricting the development of content that HL fans are wanting and are waiting for.  I'm sorry Vortal Storm, but Lambda Wars is not the game Half-Life fans want.  It's the game Half-Life 2 lore-nuts want and that alone does not make a great game even greater... it just drags it down and throws any big potential right out the window.BUT, IT'S NOT TOO LATE.  When you add more content and are more open to creativity and loads of content, I will be there as a Half-Life franchise fan.  But, until then... I'll just deal with the immense amount of disappointment that just consumed me after following this game since it's open beta on Steam.  I'll still play it, but, I am sorely disappointed and I hope that, someday, this game becomes something more than a Half-Life 2 lore orgy.

Year has passed, nothing has changed.Lambda Wars claims to be "a traditional RTS game", but does it play like one? No. Or maybe it plays like a really bad one.Now, look. The concept is great, the ideas are great, but they are nothing when around broken gameplay mechanics, which are, obviously, essential for a strategy game like Lambda Wars. And by gameplay mechanics I mean everything. The core problem is that the Combine and Rebels sides are heavily unbalanced. Early game eventually becomes a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥when you are playing as the Combine, because: Buildings take a lot of time to build Units take a lot of time to train One Metrocop takes 16 Seconds! to train There's a unit limit cap, which prevents you both from attacking the enemy AND defending yourself from constant zerg rushes by Rebels. Expanding unit limits takes a lot of money. You can't effectively secure control points, especially in the early game, which slows down the gameplay, almost making you feel sorry for choosing Combine as your sideCombine everything listed above with the fact that this game is fast paced, which means you have to rush for resources and upgrades as soon as possible.Now, "Rebels have weak units". No. They don't.Core Rebel units aren't weak, at all. They sure are weaker than a Metrocop by 20 HP, but they are so much faster to be trained. Plus, they have a wide variety of weapons, while Metrocops haven't. "Why are you comparing rebels to Metrocops and not Combine Soldiers? Combine Soldiers are stronger." Because Combine Soldiers suffer from the same problems Metrocops do - they take too much time to train. And in comparsion to a Rebel unit, they are more expensive, have a slightly bigger HP Bar, which is nothing when you have 2-3 Rebels or even Partisans against one Combine Soldier, which will be the most frequent scene you'll see when playing the game. Combine Defenses aren't great. Manned Guns are easy to take down by already mentioned groups of Partisans/Rebels, because the pilot of the gun dies rather quick, despite the defense bonus provided by the barricade. Combine Turrets are vulnerable to Rebel Saboteurs and groups of rebels/partisans. Mines are pretty much useless against these huge crowds for some reason, I don't know why. Same for Headcrab shells.Devs had also added a completely useless variation of a Metrocop, which is supposed to be a mobile defense point or something, but I couldn't see it in action, Shield-wielding Cop died almost instantly from a bunch of rebels despite the raised shield and defense stance on.I could drone on and on about all the imbalances in the game, but everything above makes it pretty clear: the game is going the wrong direction. Completely. Developers should really take C&C Franchise as a proper example of a nice RTS game, and try to implement their ideas like defensive points and scrapyard thingies in a more C&C Setting.

Al these little things together can be frustrating and it makes me curse at my little army of idiots out of annoyance.Don't get me wrong, there is definitely something here but it needs a lot more work and fine-tuning before i can fully recommend it to anyone. 												Well.... I got what I paid for. This was thoroughly uninspired and underwhelming.But, I do have a few praises to sing:The interface and camera controls are fairly similar to Starcraft, and that makes it at least pleasurable to play. I didn't fight the interface too much.It's relatively easy to tell what is what. At least it didn't look cluttered and overly complex, and the graphics are actually fine for an RTS. It's source though, so not a huge surprise there.And... that's about all it has going for it.The economic design is fairly lackluster. There are resources, but it takes minimal effort to get them, so you really can get a fully saturated economy going quite quickly. This leads to problem 2: Macro is BORING. There's just not much to do, and there's no flood of resources feeling that you get from say, 5 base Zerg in Starcraft Broodwar.Okay, not every game has to be simcity on steroids, but what about the tactics? Well, they're boring too. Infantry are fairly identical, and so early game play is just boring and 1 dimensional. Units beyond that might be somewhat interesting, but given how limited the economy is, you can't make many of them. And to make matters even worse, there's barely any tech tree at all.Overall, it feels like I'm not architecting any grand strategies, employing finessed micro, or exploiting the terrain and tactical advantages to win a match. I just feel like I'm doing the most basic routine and pressing attack-move and going to sleep. I don't feel engaged. I don't have fun using the units. I don't like the game.Bah, what did I expect?But, maybe if these guys got a real designer to sit down and actually architect a meaningful game flow, it'd be pretty good. I mean, they put all this effort into building a fairly decent RTS client for the source engine. That's kind of awesome.Until then, I'll be uninstalling.

												     Since the game is still in Beta, I can't write a legitamite review untill the game is fully realeased. However I can write about some things that I enjoy about the game and things I think need to be revised. First off I love the idea of a Half Life RTS game and I think they should keep developing it. The UI is simple but can get a little bit confusing the first time around.      Some things I think need fixed are: Rebel antlions are over-powerd and will destroy everything in their paths. The camera needs to be able to zoom in and out more. The combine needs less preparation required to build things and units need to cost less if the max units is only 100. Units should be more manageable and esier to distinguish.(Suggestion: make it possible to hotkey selected groups of units to jump quikly to them.) And lastly, make the victory and defete screens less awefull looking.      Overall the game is good and I recomend it to people who like the Half Life series, but I cannot say I recomend it to seasoned RTS players. Especialy in its current state.

												Good game, and it's free at that. Really fun to play if you like RTS games; although this isn't a typical RTS game. Rebels seem to be the easiest to play as, if only because of the fact that you can build a ton of units fast then rush the enemy with sheer force alone. If you have the hard drive space I'd get it and try it.What I'd like to see from this game in the future is maybe the ability to build vehicles like the combine APC and the Jeep/Airboat, both with and without weapons. Wouldn't be hard to do. Definitely needs more units and buildings to build. Devs need to add thsi stuff so the game matches last longer. What happens now is after 10 minutes of building my adversary and I have built everything and researched every upgrade, and now we're just sending in larger and larger armies to take eachother out.In short: free game, fun game, needs more units/buildings/upgrades. Download it.

Posted: March 20, 2015
For a Beta the gameplay is surprisingly solid, and the strategic depth offered would put certain AAA titles to shame. Especially the newer ones.I'll begin listing what I consider the pros and cons before heading on to why this is an excellent RTS:Pros: No dank "Rock, Paper, Scissor" system, no crushing "Slippery Slope", diverse and unconventional units and abilities, sticks to canon as much as possible, lot's of room for micromanagement of units, diverse maps, frequent updates. FREE with no microtransactions or DLC.Cons: Sometimes you'll have to host locally instead of using the game servers, which depending on your location might lag. Game might crash in rare circumstances, but is overal stable.Lambda Wars is like your old school assymetrical RTS games - with a twist.What makes Lambda Wars great?First of all: A lot of RTS games suffer from the "slippery slope" problem. Once you start losing it is very hard to get back on track.Lambda wars effectively solves this problem by allowing the action (Ability) of a single unit to sway the battle or even a match. For example: efficient RPG microing, a tactical grenade throw or a well manouvered Hunter dodge and charge. Even a last resort headcrab canister or dog leap can turn the game around. Most units and certain buildings come with these special (unlockable) abilities.Most RTS games also follow a stale "Rock, Paper, Scissor" recipe. Lambda Wars negates this. The effectiveness of a unit depends on its position, how it is micro'd and the composition of the force you are using as a whole. Not the hard counters many RTS games implement. (Swords beating bows, tanks beating infantry, etc.)Combine Elites can be used against Striders, and Veterans (Crossbow rebels) can wipe the floor with dogs. Yet it is also possible for the latter to beat the previous, even if the size of the force remains the same. Even resource starved teams and players can beat those that nearly control every flag. Late game units and structures aren't "insta win" buttons like in many strategy games. Barring a few abilities (like the explosive crossbow bolt) the game also tends to stick to the canon. The music captures the atmosphere of the game and the HL2 universe as a whole, while the sound effects are a mix between those imported from the base HL2 game and newly creates ones. While sometimes they don't seem to play when you select a unit or building, they are characteristic and not overwhelming. Though some of the effects are a bit too loud in my opinion.Besides that there are several gamemodes ranging from traditional "Annihilation" (destroying all enemy units and production buildings) to "Overrun", where you attempt to stave off increasingly large and more powerful hordes of zombies.Maps range from 8 player FFA zombie overrun frozen wastelands to smaller 1vs1 canyon style maps. There is enough variety to allow for continuous replayability. A sandbox mode is also included.Also note that both Rebels and Combine differ a bit in their resource gathering. While both require "Requisition" gained by captured (and upgraded - which increases earnings) flags, the Combine gather - generator generated - Energy as their secondary resource (which they need to store using batteries) while the Rebels gather scrap from (a limited amount of) scrap heaps.Without doubt I consider Lambda Wars as it is one of the best RTS games I have ever played (and I've played many in a 15 year time period, especially the classics), and it also ranks highly in my top 10 of best Source mods. If this is the Beta, then I have very high hopes for the full version.
